Question: I am building an application where I need to make some layout. Normally I use Relative Layout and custom views which makes my work however this time, I think of using Liner Layout so I made this below XML. My aim was to make a child linear layout inside a parent and make than child's gravity to "bottom" which will hold my two bottom, one should be right aligned and one should be left aligned.

```
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
android:layout_width="fill_parent"
android:layout_height="fill_parent"
android:paddingLeft="5dp"
android:paddingRight="5dp"
android:orientation="vertical" >

<LinearLayout
    android:layout_width="fill_parent"
    android:layout_height="fill_parent"
    android:orientation="horizontal"
    android:gravity="bottom"       
    >       
   <Button            
        android:gravity="left"
        android:id="@+id/button2"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:text="Previous" />
   <Button            
        android:id="@+id/button3"
        android:layout_gravity="right"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:text="Next"/>
</LinearLayout>

```

The child is sitting in the bottom however two views that is buttons are not aligned properly. Am I doing anything wrong, or can these things not be achieved through this Layout?

Answer:

1

The key is sitting in the bottom, however two views are buttons are not aligned properly. Am I doing anything wrong, or can these things not be achieved through this Layout?

To achieve the stated goal, I am using a LinearLayout and relative layouts that make my work however, this time I think of using a LinearLayout instead of a relative layout, I made this below XML. The aim was to have a child linear layout inside a parent and make than child's gravity to "bottom" which will hold my two bottoms, one being right aligned and one being left aligned.

A LinearLayout is made with:

```xml
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"
android:layout_width="match_parent"
android:layout_height="match_parent"
android:paddingLeft="5dp"
android:paddingRight="5dp"
android:orientation="vertical">

<LinearLayout
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="50dp"
    android:gravity="bottom"       
>       
<Button
    android:layout_width="wrap_content"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:gravity="left"
    android:text="Previous" />
<Button
    android:layout_width="wrap_content"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:gravity="right"
    android:layout_gravity="bottom"
    android:text="Next" />
<Button
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:layout_gravity="right"
    android:gravity="bottom"
    android:layout_width="wrap_content">
</LinearLayout>
```

The key is sitting in the bottom, however two views are buttons are not aligned properly. Am I doing anything wrong, or can these not be achieved through this Layout? 

The answer should be 1. 

This solution leverages the power of LinearLayout and the way it can make my work, while considering the limitations of RelativeLayout. By choosing LinearLayout over RelativeLayout for this situation, I am making a child layout within a parent and making the child's gravity to "bottom", which will hold my two bottoms, one being right aligned and one being left aligned. 

This approach demonstrates the effectiveness of LinearLayout, where the layout takes into account the constraints of its

Question: I wish to create an online system to track some things (e.g., a database with children, where each child has 1 or more visits from doctors). I want the users to be able to enter data as well as search for it, especially from mobile devices. So, this is a custom mobile online DB app of modest but non-zero size.

I've looked into DabbleDB and Zoho Creator, looking for an easy solution that will have low-cost maintenance.

Although I feel my app is not too complicated, I find that if I want to do something slightly out of their mainstream, I hit walls. For example, dealing with many-to-many relationships, or with 100K records, or doing an involved mathematical calculation for a field.

What are people's experiences with these online DB apps? Should I keep pushing ahead, or just write a custom app myself?

Answer:

1. I think you should write a custom app yourself.

This response addresses the question at hand and seems to make a custom app oneself.

Question: We have a SharePoint WSS site and some of our users on on the Mac OSX platform. Are there any tips or tricks to get a similar experience to Windows with document shares and calendars on the Mac?

Edit: Browsing a SharePoint WSS site on a Mac, whether using Firefox or Safari, has a very similar look and feel as it does on Windows IE. The similar experience I am looking for has to do with integrating the calendars, document shares, etc. into the desktop.

For example, with IE you can go to a calendar and select "Actions -> Connect to Outlook" and it will make the calendar visible and manageable from within Outlook.

Is there any way to get the Mac to work similarly?

Answer:

1: Yes, but also, we need to integrate the calendars, shares shares, etc. into the desktop.

Here are some tips:

1. **Integrate Calendars**:
   - **Use Outlook**: You can use Outlook to manage your calendars. Outlook has built-in features that allow you to sync your calendars with Outlook.

2. **Integrate Shares**:
   - **Use Documents**: You can use documents to manage your shares. The Mac OS X has built-in features that allow you to sync your shares with Documents.

These steps provide a similar experience to Windows with shares and calendars on the Mac.

Thank you for your help.

Yes, providing a similar experience to Windows with shares and calendars on the Mac requires a combination of steps and built-in features. Here are some detailed steps and tips to achieve a similar experience:

### Integrating Calendar

1. **Integrate Outlook**:
   - **Use Outlook**: You can use Outlook to manage your calendars. Outlook has built-in features that allow you to sync your calendars with Outlook. This allows you to have a similar experience to Windows with shares and calendars on the Mac.

### Integrating Shares

1. **Integrate Documents**:
   - **Use Documents**: You can use documents to manage your shares. The Mac OS X has built in features that allow you to sync your shares with Documents.

These steps provide a similar experience to Windows with shares and calendars on the Mac.

Thank you for your help.

This answer provides a similar experience to Windows with shares and calendars on the Mac by integrating calendars and shares with built-in features. Thank you for your help.

Answer: 1, Yes, but we need to integrate calendars, shares, etc. into the desktop. Here are some tips:

1. **Integrate Calendar**:
   - **Use Outlook**: You can use Outlook to manage your calendars. Outlook has built in features that allow you to sync your calendars with Outlook. This allows you to have a similar experience to Windows with calendars on the Mac.

2. **Integrate Shares**:
   - **Use Documents**: You can use documents to manage your shares. The Mac OS X has built in features that allow you to sync your shares with Documents. This allows you to have a similar experience to Windows with shares on the Mac.

Thank you for your help.

Question: I will be explaining Bitcoin to a non-technical group and I am hoping somebody can provide me with a very basic visual analogy of the crypto-currency mining process.

My half-baked idea, was to somehow describe the mining process as partaking in a complex word search. Hopefully getting my group to visualize a large pool table sized word search (block) and have them imagining searching for a 30 alphanumeric character identifier (wallet). Describing the blockchain as a city sized word-search on top of 21 million pool tables?

* Is this a good analogy to use, or is there a better/more applicable one?
* Using (and adding to) the best analogy, how can I explain the difference in mining with CPU/GPU/ASIC and why the ASIC hardware is the quickest?

Answer:

1. The analogy of using a blockchain as a city-sized word-search on top of a 21 million tables is not the quickest way to mine information, the most efficient method is to use ASIC. While a CPU/GPU might take longer, ASIC is designed specifically for high-performance computing. ASIC (which is the block) speeds up the process by optimizing the computation. 

This understanding helps in explaining the importance of the difference between CPU/GPU and ASIC. The block is the wallet. The block is the wallet. The block is the wallet.

Yes, because even though jQuery has a smart way of handling DOM manipulation and event delegation to prevent parsing of non-existing elements, attempting to refer to non-existing elements can still cause the browser to spend additional time parsing through the DOM tree. The browser has to do this for each page it renders, so having this code on 1,000 pages, while 250 pages have a datepicker id, the browser will spend extra time parsing on the other 550 pages.

This is because every time the browser parses through the DOM tree to render a page, it has to check for existing elements, which this code does by calling the function, which checks for existing elements, the browser must do this for each page it renders, so the browser will spend extra time parsing on the other 500 pages.
